title: Attack of the Cybermen
writers: Paula Moore (pseudonym for Paula Wolsey, Eric Saward)
dialogue_disasters: Lytton: 'I can understand why they call them tombs.'
goofs: The Cybercontroller has a bit of a tummy on him.
The Cyberman guarding the Doctor and Flast tries to extinguish his flaming arm by batting it with his gun.
The Cyberman's head that the Doctor investigates, searching for the distress signal, contains no organic parts.
When Lytton stabs the Cybercontroller some of the green fluid squirts onto the camera lens.
Towards the end, when a Cyberman realises that Cyber Control is soon going to blow up, he makes 'leg it' motions to his companion.
A Cyberman seems to say 'It is a Fat Controller.'

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time machine and spacecraft
continuity_notes.current_status: Chameleon circuit temporarily repaired, allowing it to change appearance

continuity_notes.name: Cybermen
continuity_notes.description: Cybernetic humanoids, enemies of the Doctor
continuity_notes.current_status: Weaker than previously seen, vulnerable to bullets and sonic lance

continuity_notes.name: Time Lords
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's race, capable of manipulating time
continuity_notes.current_status: Implied to have engineered the Doctor's involvement to protect the web of time

continuity_notes.name: Lytton
continuity_notes.description: A mercenary previously encountered by the Doctor
continuity_notes.origin: Satellite of Vita 15 (Riften 5) in star system 690
continuity_notes.current_status: Working with the Cryons against the Cybermen

technobabble: The TARDIS shell, if punctured, would expose occupants to a vacuum
The Doctor can set the TARDIS to self-destruct
roots: The bank robbery subplot is drawn from the productions of Euston Films
Visual and musical references to Steptoe and Son
links: The Doctor calls Peri 'Tegan', 'Zoe', 'Susan', 'Jamie' and 'the Terrible Zodin' (referencing 'The Five Doctors')

locations.name: Telos
locations.current_status: Setting for events in the future

locations.name: 76 Totter's Lane
locations.description: Address where the TARDIS materializes, 22 years after 'An Unearthly Child'
locations.current_status: Location of I. M. Foreman's yard

untold_adventures: Possible untelevised adventure where the Doctor met Lytton before 'Resurrection of the Daleks'
additional_notes: The episode features increased violence, including a fight between the Doctor and a policeman, and Lytton's hands being crushed.
bottom_line: A disappointing and overly complex Cybermen story that cheapens the memory of 'The Tomb of the Cybermen' and tries to tie up too many loose ends.
